utterances: That's right.
I took the group that voted for him and matched that to Bush's record in their states, and it turned out that half of that group were from states where Bush won in 2004.
So I think what we're looking at here, underneath the table, is really the political influence of the president.
Ron Walters is a professor of political science at the University of Maryland.
He was an adviser to Reverend Jackson's campaigns for president.
And Reverend Joseph Watkins, head of Christ Evangelical Lutheran Church in Philadelphia and a member of the first President Bush's White House staff.
Gentlemen, thanks so much for being with us on Political Corner.
Thank you, Juan.
Thank you, Juan.
Join us every Thursday to hear more from Juan Williams and our Washington insiders right here on Political Corner.
Down the coast from Natori lies the Fukushima Dai-chi nuclear power plant.
The tsunami crashed into that facility a year ago and triggered three meltdowns.
The world watched with alarm as large clouds of radioactive material steamed from the reactors.
Some 170,000 people were evacuated from homes near the plant.
Joining us now for an update on the nuclear accident and its consequences is NPR science correspondent Richard Harris.
Richard, I know you're fighting some throat problems.
Thanks very much for being with us.
Yeah.
Sorry for the voice, but I'll do what I can here.
What is the situation with the plant right now?
Well, I would say it's a stable mess.
The nuclear fuel has been cooled down with water so it's not hot, hot, hot anymore - although it's still highly radioactive.
Probably at least one of the three reactors have actually melted down - the cores have melted down through the bottom of its container.
So this core is now sitting in an outer container made of steel and concrete.
They're still pumping a huge amount of water through the plants to keep them cool, and then the water runs through multiple filters so they can remove the radioactive material from it.
So right now, radioactive releases from the plant are minimal, and they're starting to turn the corner to clean up the mess - which is going to take decades.
Because thousands - we're talking about thousands - of square miles of land around the nuclear power station.
Any idea of when this land is going to be habitable again?
Well, it's very hard to say.
There's still a 12-mile, essentially, evacuation zone and they're trying to clean it up.
And they're using hoses to hose down the contaminated material, and scraping off radioactive soils.
But the levels are still higher than normal background levels, and people don't really know what level they will consider to be safe and comfortable living there.
So that's still being debated right now.
Well, first of all, in fact, he was confirm his comment that he's not going to leave Iraqis at this very hard time.
And he's going to fulfill the mission before decide to withdraw troops from Iraq, and he has his own option.
And he's not going to be committed at this stage, in fact, when he - with any recommendation given to him and be circulated.
On the other hand, he was shocked by the killing between the Iraqis themselves.
He said, I can't understand this sort of killing.
And at the same time, he said that America will continue help Iraqis to help themselves, which is good.
The unending violence has really taken a toll on the Iraqi people.
You yourself have been touched.
I understand you lost three siblings?
Three, yes.
This is just part of, of course, that everybody is (unintelligible).
This is not a unique - even the leaders of the country.
So everybody exposed to high cost, so I share my cost from my own family.
I read where you had spoken to a policy group.
You were trying to describe for them, if this were happening in America, what it would - in the United States - what it would be like.
Can you tell me that analogy?
I was talking about the infiltrations of the militias, in fact, inside the security forces.
How do you visualize your security forces if the management of those security forces going to be run by KKK?
This what I have said.
So I made a short (unintelligible) to the audience about that.
How did it get to this level in your country that people are killing one another at such high rates?
It wasn't the case in the past before, the invasion of Iraq.
And we do have a different sects, there is no doubt about that.
We have different ethnics.
Different religions.
That seems to be a good formula, in fact, for Iraq over centuries.

So whoever might be interest to divide and to harm the social fabric of Iraq is in fact try to capitalize on this variety and so forth of social groups and make things rather difficult and then make this sectarian tension.
You yourself are Sunni.
I'm wondering what kind of an influence you have with the Sunni insurgents.
I do have - I could reach them easily, and but they have their own strategy.

They don't have - they have their own leadership, but I need to be close with them because I do know that their bottom line for this struggle is that to see Iraq as free and all the foreign troops to pull out sometime.
This is the ultimate goal of what they are doing time being.

Their resistance, as I understand, in fact, is going to continue until a clear-cut message delivered by the American administration that there will be a timetable withdrawal, and I hope sincerely that the recommendation given by James Baker, Lee Hamilton recommendation is going to be taken care of seriously.
Mr.
Vice President, there are reports that you've been working behind the scenes to form a new parliamentary block that could in fact topple the government.
Is that something that you would like to see?
Do you think Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki should be replaced?
I do have reservations about his performances so far.
I was very clear in this regard.
Even I openly talk to him about that, and I am not hiding my anger about the government performances in general.
But I am not trying in fact to throw him away by this sort of organization, or preparation that I am doing so.

On the contrary, there is now an option that is still under consideration to have an alliance between the moderate parties who are in power so far, to kick out or to isolate the extremists from both Shia and Sunni.
How would you restructure the government, if you could make a plan and present it?
There will be a problem, in fact, unless the government line up behind the common interest of Iraq.
What we need is a real patriotic government, non-ethnic, non-sectarian loyalty.
This is the only way to salvage Iraq.
Do you think that that is possible?
I mean, there are those who have said...
It's not difficult anyway.
I can't see it difficult.
It's on the contrary.
I think it would put all the differences between ethnics and sectors aside and go ahead for the common interest that the majority of Iraqis are - could live with them.
You've spent time this week in the United States, making your case to different groups and leaders about what is going on in Iraq.
What is your main message you're trying to get across to the American people on this visit?
Well, first all, I would like to say that actually we do have a common interest now in Iraq.
America has been committed from the beginning, after the collapse of Saddam Hussein to rebuild an Iraq of unique features in the Middle East, that my people are still dreaming for that.
And they're not going to achieve that without the assistance of the Americans.
I don't want them, in fact, to let me down at this very, very hard time.
What I need is their continuous support until my country, my people is salvaged, and get out of this current dilemma.
Thank you for speaking with us.
Thank you very much.
Tareq al-Hashemi is vice president of Iraq.
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Hillary Rodham Clinton started out her professional life as Hillary Rodham.
But she decided to join the majority of married women and take her husband's last name.
In fact, more than 80 percent of women in the U.S.
change their name when they get married.
Commentator Diana Boxer says that there are more and more women making the same choice.
Many of us who are of a certain age and philosophy are surprised by this trend.
The slogans we've lived by include, the personal is political, and later, having it all.
And that included our surnames.
But according to my recent research on the issue, that's so 70s.
Women who keep their names after marriage are known, sometimes disparagingly, as Lucy Stoners after suffragette Lucy Stone, the first woman to legally keep her own last name way back in 1855.
But an interesting survey a few years ago showed that a majority of Midwesterners at least think of Lucy Stoner as a negative tone.
Not religious, not good cooks - and here's the clincher - not good wives.
The radioactive material does decay gradually, over time, and some of these particles will get buried in the soil and so on.
But some of this material will remain radioactive for centuries.
So I think it's fair to say that some of these areas may be reinhabited in a few years, but it's likely the other areas will remain off-limits for decades, or maybe even longer.
What happened to people who got exposed to radiation during the accident?
Well, amazingly enough, health experts say that nobody got enough radiation exposure to result in any really identifiable health risks.
If you assume that there's no safe dose of radiation, there would be a very small increase in cancers in Japan.
But that increase would be far too small to measure.
In fact, it's possible there's no added risk at all to the general public.
Some workers got extra doses and that's a concern as well, but even they didn't get doses that are known to cause health effects.
What really looms large are the psychological issues.
Let's not forget, the meltdowns came on top of this earthquake, the tsunami, the evacuations.
Many people lost their livelihoods because there's not much of a market for local fish and produce.
So those are really overwhelming impacts, on top of the fear and the unknown about radiation.
With these reactors and so many others shut down, how is Japan powering itself these days?
It's been very difficult, actually, partly because the federal government in Japan has let local officials decide whether to restart reactors once they shut down for routine maintenance.
Right now, there are only two of the 54 reactors in the country still running, and those last two will probably be shut down later this spring.
So there's almost no nuclear power in Japan now, and there will be none.
And it had been providing 30 percent of the nation's electricity.
So they're now relying more heavily on imports of coal and natural gas, which are both expensive and more polluting.
They're also trying to conserve electricity - wearing short sleeves in the summer and turning up the thermostats, and things like that.
NPR science correspondent Richard Harris.
Thanks so much.
My pleasure.
And there are growing tensions between Muslims and Christians in Egypt that have led to sporadic violence there.
The attacks are part of a larger crime wave sweeping the country.
Many Egyptians blame the interreligious strife on hooligans taking advantage of absent or weak security forces.
Others believe it's because of a deep-seated mistrust between Muslims and the minority Christian community.
The lack of trust seems to be growing as Islamists emerge as the country's main political force, and Christians in some communities are being driven from their homes.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson visited one of these villages and filed this report.
(SOUNDBITE OF FOOTSTEPS)
